answer.body:
A Sector Administrator is a co-regulator that assists the COC to oversee the charities and IPCs in their respective sectors. There are 5 Sector Administrators, as follows:

  • Ministry of Education – Education                   

  • Ministry of Health - Health                              

  • Ministry of Social and Family Development – Social and Welfare   Services                                          

  • People’s Association – Community             

  • Sport Singapore – Sports

 

Charities and IPCs that do not fall neatly under these sectors will come under the direct purview of the Office of the COC. These include charities and IPCs in the Religious, Arts and Heritage, Animal welfare, Environmental protection or improvement and all other sectors. They will report directly to CU on matters relating to charities/IPC status and governance issues.

The charity sector is regulated by five Sector Administrators (SAs) and the Commissioner of Charities. The 5 sectors and the 5 Sector Administrators are, respectively:

  • Education - Ministry of Education (MOE)

  • Health - Ministry of Health (MOH)

  • Social Welfare Services - Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF)

  • Community - People's Association (PA)

  • Sports - Sport Singapore

 

Charities and IPCs that do not fall neatly under these sectors would be regulated directly under the purview of the Commissioner of Charities (COC). Organisations with multiple charitable objectives can submit their applications to the Office of the COC, who will decide which SA will take charge of the charity.

answer.body:
“Large Charity” refers to a charity with gross annual receipts in each financial year of not less than $10 million in the two financial years immediately preceding the current financial year of the charity.

Large charities are subject to the Charities (Large Charities) Regulations.

questionListItems.title: How to submit an IPC application?

answer.body:
A registered charity may submit an “Application for Approval as an IPC” via the Charity Portal – if it is applying for IPC status for the first time.


For existing IPCs who are applying for its approval as an IPC to be extended, please submit an “Application for Extension as an IPC”.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: What are the legislations/ regulations/ rules/ requirements that an IPC has to abide by?

answer.body: IPCs must comply with the Charities (Institutions of a Public Character) Regulations which covers areas such as the board independence, fund-raising, duty to donors, use of donations, duty to maintain donation records, accounting records, etc.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Is the revised Code mandatory? Are all charities required to apply the revised Code? What is the implication if charities do not apply the Code?

answer.body:
• The Code operates on the principle of ‘comply or explain’. The Code applies to all registered charities.


  • The Code does not apply to Exempt Charities and self-funded grantmakers which do not have IPC status, such as philanthropic foundations funded with private family or institutional money. They are strongly encouraged to refer to the Code as a matter of best practice.


  • While compliance with the Code is not mandatory, charities to whom the Code applies, are required to submit a GEC on the Charity Portal. In the GEC, charities should:

    • explain why it cannot comply or can only partially comply with certain Code guidelines;

    • indicate the steps it plans to take to comply or explain why if it decides not to comply; and

    • the Board and Management must approve the GEC before submission on the Charity Portal.


  • Charities, which are not IPCs, have gross annual receipts (or total expenditure, whichever is higher) of less than $50,000 are not required to submit the GEC. However, they are strongly encouraged to adhere to the principles of the Code.


  • For IPCs, their respective Sector Administrators (SAs) would consider the IPC’s extent of Code compliance, and the reasons for partial compliance and/or non-compliance, when assessing an IPC’s application to extend its IPC status, as well as the length of IPC extension.

Also known as the Office of the Commissioner of Charities (COC), Charities Unit is a division of the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY). CU's vision is to develop a well-governed and thriving charity sector with strong public support. The objectives of the COC are:

  • To maintain public trust and confidence in charities;

  • To promote compliance by governing board members and key officers with their legal obligations in exercising control and management of the administration of their charities;

  • To promote the effective use of charitable resources; and

  • To enhance the accountability of charities to donors, beneficiaries and the general public.

questionListItems.title: What is the role of Charities Unit (CU)?

answer.body:
Its roles include:

  • Ensuring Regulatory Compliance

  • Example:

    • Registration and De-registration of charities

    • Review of Annual Reports and Financial Statements

    • Undertake enforcement action on errant charities

 

  • Promoting Good Governance & Best Practices

  • Example:

    • Enhance effectiveness of charities

    • Promote best practices

    • Enhance public confidence

    • Providing funding and support through Charities Capability Fund (CCF)

 

  • Becoming a Proactive Advisory on Charity Matters

  • Example:

    • Understand the charity’s/Institution of a Public Character (IPC)’s programmes and activities

    • Share good governance and best practices

    • Provide charities/IPCs with guides and resources

    • Build long-term relationships with charities/IPCs.

questionListItems.title: What are the legislations/regulations/rules/requirements that charities must abide by?

answer.body:
Charities have to abide by the Charities Act and Regulations that outline the legislative requirements on registration, deregistration, submission of accounts, reports and returns, fund-raising and others.


These include:

  • Charities Act

  • Charities (Accounts and Annual Report) Regulations

  • Charities (Fund-Raising Appeals for Local and Foreign Charitable Purposes) Regulations

  • Charities (Large Charities) Regulations

  • Charities (Registration of Charities) Regulations

 

For IPCs, they would also have to comply with the Charities (Institutions of a Public Character) Regulations. The legislation and regulations are available on the Charity Portal or Singapore Statutes online.

A charity, as defined in the Charities Act, refers to an organisation established for exclusively charitable purposes.


 In addition, the organisation must conduct activities in furtherance of its charitable purposes which benefit the public. An organisation that meets the requirements must apply to the Commissioner of Charities to be registered as a charity within three (3) months of its establishment.

 

A registered charity will enjoy automatic income tax exemption. For properties which are used for exclusively charitable purposes, property tax may be exempted in full or partially upon application and reviewed by the Comptroller of Property Tax.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Is charity considered a legal entity on its own?

answer.body:
No. Charity is a status conferred to the organisation, and does not accord any legal entity status. Hence, an organisation has to be first set up as a legal entity either with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) as a Company Limited by Guarantee; or with Registry of Societies (ROS) as a society; or as a Charitable Trust before registering as a charity.

 

The type of legal structure an organisation chooses affects how it operates. Hence, do consult professional/legal advice to consider the various requirements and obligations under the respective set-up before deciding how the organisation is to be established.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What is a Company Limited by Guarantee (CLG)?

answer.body:
A company limited by guarantee is formed by at least one person at the time of incorporation.  It is a public company that is generally set up for non-profit purposes and does not have a share capital. In the absence of the share capital, a guarantee is provided by the member(s) of the company, which is set out in its Constitution (formerly known as Memorandum & Articles of Association). The guarantee states that the member(s) undertakes to contribute to assets of the company for the payment of debts and liabilities if the company is wound up. The Companies Act also prescribes other requirements for incorporation as a company limited by guarantee and can be found on ACRA’s website.


The liability of the members is limited to the amount of guarantee provided to the company.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

answer.body:
A society is generally formed by a group of like-minded people coming together to pursue a common interest in accordance with the objectives and rules of their constitution.

 

Any group of 10 or more persons may be granted registration under the Societies Act, if it is not registered under any other law in Singapore. A society is self-governing, as its members will typically elect from among themselves a management committee to look after its day-to-day affairs. Other requirements for a Society are spelt out in the Societies Act, which can be found at the Registry of Societies website.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

answer.body:
A trust is a relationship in which one person holds title to property, subject to an obligation to keep or use the property for the benefit of another. Trusts are governed under the Trustees Act, including charitable trusts.


A charitable trust can be created when a donor, either during his lifetime or by will, makes a gift to charity, appointing trustee(s) to hold the gift in trust and to use it for the charitable purposes as specified in the trust.


A trust has no independent legal entity status and thus, trustees will be responsible for legal liabilities arising from the trust.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

answer.body:
A parent organisation (which is either a company limited by guarantee, society or a trust) may set up a fund for a specific purpose (e.g. welfare fund). The fund does not have a separate legal entity status as it falls under the umbrella of the parent organisation. Funds are governed by their specific Rules & Regulations.

Members do not enjoy separate legal identity status and are thus exposed to liability issues.
